awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Tapis Advancing Collaborative Open Source (TACOS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The advanced computing infrastructure landscape has evolved tremendously with many sophisticated capabilities for tackling the world's most challenging computing problems. But with that sophistication comes complexity. The Tapis Framework provides a hosted, unified web-based API for securely managing computational workloads across institutions so that experts can focus on their research instead of the technology needed to accomplish it. The Tapis Advancing Collaborative Open Source (TACOS) initiative seeks to explore transforming Tapis into  a  self-sustaining  organization. TACOS  will  look  for  the  tools,  services,  and  infrastructure  support needed  to  transform into an Open Source Ecosystem (OSE) and enable Tapis to expand to a collaborative and asynchronous development environment.
 
The Tapis platform allows easier implementation, sharing and re-use of complex computational applications, workflows, and infrastructure and enables analysis previously too challenging for researchers. Tapis maximizes application portability, allowing flexible scheduling of geographically distributed computational workloads, offering a HTTP-based RESTful API science-as-a-service to enable multi-facility, decentralized deployments, and provide production-grade support for sensors and streaming data. By transforming Tapis to an Open Source Ecosystem, Tapis leadership will establish organization and governance structures along with contribution pathways and processes for the greater community ecosystem, including reusable Tapis artifacts such as containerized functions, applications and Jupyter notebooks, in addition to the core code base. Tools to accelerate community development, such as push-button sandbox environments, template and scaffold libraries for SDK, CLI and user interfaces, will also be identified and adopted.
 
The project’s primary objectives will be to grow and strengthen the engagement of developer communities to provide long-term sustainment. These engagements will look at opportunities to shift the community from not only being users of Tapis but also contributors to Tapis. The project team believes deeply in the power and importance of an open, inclusive, community driven approach to software development, and the POSE program will enable us to create inroads to direct engagement by the developer community. By making Tapis an OSE, going beyond source code, Tapis will evolve to an ecosystem of components that the community can contribute to at any level of expertise. To this end the project will engage beyond existing user base and pursue community members amongst teaching intensive institutes and EPSCOR communities via student mentoring and hackathons to broaden outreach and create opportunities to contribute to the Tapis ecosystem.

Further details about the Tapis project can be found on https://tapis-project.org/ including a getting started guide at https://tapis.readthedocs.io/en/latest/. The wider Tapis community is available to join using Slack at: http://bit.ly/join-tapis

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of robust cyberinfrastructure (CI) is to become a catalyst for discovery and innovation by fostering the development of software frameworks as sustainable production-quality services. The NSF-funded Tapis project (NSF OAC #1931439) simplifies the development and deployment of complex computational applications and workflows, allowing research teams to leverage advanced and heterogeneous cyberinfrastructure in automated ways that would otherwise be prohibitively challenging. Using Tapis, researchers share and re-use digital assets, including datasets, metadata, executable functions, and applications. Using container technology, Tapis maximizes application portability, allowing flexible scheduling of geographically distributed computational workloads via an HTTP-based RESTful application programming interface (API). Tapis empowers data-driven discovery across a broad range of domains of science and engineering. The platform is used by major projects funded by agencies including the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Through the NSF POSE: Phase I: Tapis Advancing Collaborative Open Source (TACOS) award #2229614 Tapis engaged and scoped the viability of launching an Open Source Ecosystem (OSE) through evaluations and landscape discovery to maximize the impact and sustainability of Tapis.

Through funding provided by a POSE phase 1 planning grant, the project team met the objectives set forth in the proposal. The Tapis executive team conducted a detailed product comparison of Tapis against nearly 30 academic and commercial offerings within the technology landscape. This evaluation established that several primary capabilities, including the ability to define custom storage and execution resources as well as custom applications, distinguished Tapis from other offerings. As part of the program, the leadership team attended the POSE training program and gained valuable insight on customer identification, governance models, licensing and more. This multi-week training helped the team develop ideas for how to best proceed with establishing a sustainable OSE and created a networking opportunity to engage other projects doing the same. Through regular executive board meetings the team established valuable deliverables including: establishing working groups, community engagement via user meetings, hackathons and trainings, and evaluating the Tapis community. In collaboration with the Expanding Pathways in Computing (EPIC) STEM Evaluation Services, the team worked to identify potential users and stakeholder groups with interest in engaging in a Tapis OSE. An initial Tapis User survey collected input from users in numerous fields of study and confirmed the usefulness of Tapis across a wide range of functions, including data visualization and analysis, data storage and management, code execution via apps and actors, and dissemination of data and other resources to others within their community. Responders identified areas of improvement for Tapis to become a self-sustaining, collaborative OSE, including documentation, tutorials, and code examples. The Tapis executive team developed a governance model for the OSE and created an inaugural External Advisory Board composed of distinguished individuals from various institutions. Additionally, the results of this phase 1 project informed our plans for community engagement, ecosystem establishment and growth, continuous development, and methods for evaluating the OSE effectiveness moving forward with Tapis. The Tapis team also conducted outreach at PEARC23 through the annual Tapis user meeting to gather input and inform the community of the intention to establish Tapis as an OSE.  Additionally, the team held several workshops on Tapis at Science Gateways22 and PEARC23 to expand the user community. The team also engaged other community stakeholders including the NSF ICICLE Project and the NSF SGX3 Center of Excellence.  

Using the tools and knowledge developed during this Phase 1 project the Tapis team will continue the effort of sustainability via an OpenTapis platform to allow for easier implementation, contribution, sharing and re-use of complex computational applications, workflows, and infrastructure and enable analysis previously too challenging for researchers. These efforts are meant to cement an open-source ecosystem that will create software that will be sustainable through community expansion and growth.
